xxl.collections
Class Container

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.collections.Container
Direct Known Subclasses:
BlockFileContainer, DecoratorContainer, EmptyContainer, MapContainer
public abstract class Container
extends Object

A container is the top class for all classes that deal with the management of a set of objects.

A container represents a set of items, known as its elements. An element is a tuple consisting of an identifier id and an object. An object in a container can only be retrieved when the corresponding identifier is given. When inserting an object, the container creates a new id for this object and returns it to the caller. When an object is deleted from a container, its id can be reused again.

An iterator is frequently used to retrieve the ids of a container, see the method ids(). Moreover, a cursor is already implemented that supports the direct access to the objects, see the method objects(). When a collection is closed (see method close()) the iterators and cursors can be in illegal states. It might be that an iterator will still deliver data although the corresponding container is already closed.

When an element is directly deleted from a container via remove() or an element is inserted into a container via insert(), the iterators and cursors can be in an illegal state, see also the discussion in the previous paragraph. Note that iterators and cursors may also have an operation remove(). In particular, the remove() operation of an iterator should not rely on the remove() operation of Container. When remove() of an iterator is called, the iterator will still be in a valid state. HOWEVER, the other iterators of the corresponding container can be in illegal states. A similar problem occurs for updates. When a cursor updates an element of the container, the other iterators (and cursors) can be in illegal states. When a user of this class is interested in a more restrictive semantic, he/she is advised to implement the abstract methods ids() and objects() adequately. Note, that these are the only methods for generating iterators operating directly on a container.

Subclasses of Container are available which manage the data in main memory (e.g. MapContainer) and external storage. The later case will be more common. In order to reduce the number of accesses to external memory, a buffer can be used to keep "interesting" data in main memory. This aspect has some impact on the Container class. Many of the methods below offer a parameter unfix. If true, the underlying buffer can remove a specified object from memory. Otherwise (unfix == false), the buffer cannot remove the object. If the object is fixed, the object can only be removed from memory if the method unfix() is called firstly. When a container uses a buffer, the method flush() has to be implemented. The method writes back the modified objects from the buffer to the container.

See Also:
Converter, Cursor, Cursors, Function, Iterator, Mapper, NoSuchElementException

Field Detail

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function FACTORY_METHOD
A factory method to create a default Container. Each implementation of Container should have a function FACTORY_METHOD that implements two variants of invoke()
  • Object invoke():
    • returns new Container().
  • Object invoke(Object[] internalDataStructure):
    • returns new Container((<InternalDataStructure>)internalDataStructure[0]).
This field is set to MapContainer.FACTORY_METHOD.
See Also:
Function.invoke(), Function.invoke(Object[])
Constructor Detail

Container

public Container()
Sole constructor. (For invocation by subclass constructors, typically implicit.)
Method Detail

clear

public void clear()
Removes all elements from the Container. After a call of this method, size() will return 0.
Note, that the implementation of this method relies on the remove operation of the iterator returned by the method ids().

close

public void close()
Closes the Container and releases all sources. For external containers, this method closes the files immediately. MOREOVER, all iterators operating on the container can be in illegal states. Close can be called a second time without any impact. The default implementation of close is empty (which is OK for a MapContainer).
Note, that it would be desirable that the finalize-mechanism of Java would already offer the functionality of close. However, finalize does not release the sources immediately! Consequently, the corresponding file of a "closed" Container may be opened and some of the data is still not written back. This is a problem when for example the JVM stops running (because of a system error).

contains

public boolean contains(Object id)
Returns true if the container contains an object for the identifier id.
Note, that when a user would like to store null objects in a container this method has to be reimplemented.
Parameters:
id - identifier of the object.
Returns:
true if the container contains an object for the specified identifier.

flush

public void flush()
Flushes all modified elements from the buffer into the container. After this call the buffer and the container are synchronized. The default implementation of flush is empty which is OK for an unbuffered container.

flush

public void flush(Object id)
Flushes the object with identifier id from the buffer into the container.
Parameters:
id - identifier of the object that should be written back.

get

public abstract Object get(Object id,
                           boolean unfix)
                    throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the object associated to the identifier id. An exception is thrown when the desired object is not found. If unfix, the object can be removed from the underlying buffer. Otherwise (!unfix), the object has to be kept in the buffer.
Parameters:
id - identifier of the object.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the object associated to the specified identifier.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the desired object is not found.

get

public Object get(Object id)
Returns the object associated to the identifier id. It is equivalent to get(id, true).
Parameters:
id - identifier of the object.
Returns:
the object associated to the specified identifier.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the desired object is not found.

getAll

public Iterator getAll(Iterator ids,
                       boolean unfix)
Returns an iterator referring to the objects of the identifiers which are delivered by the iterator idss. The parameter unfix specifies whether the object can be removed from the buffer, see also the discussion of the method get().
The default implementation of this method is lazy, i. e. when the output iterator should deliver the next element, next is called for the input iterator.
Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers.
unfix - signals whether the objects of the iterator can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
an iterator of objects.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if one of the desired objects is not found.

getAll

public Iterator getAll(Iterator ids)
Returns an iterator pointing to the Object of the given ids. It behaves like a call of getAll(ids, true).
Parameters:
ids - an iterator of object identifiers.
Returns:
an iterator of objects.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if one of the desired objects is not found.

ids

public abstract Iterator ids()
Returns an iterator that deliver the identifiers of all objects of the container.
Returns:
an iterator of object identifiers.

insert

public abstract Object insert(Object object,
                              boolean unfix)
Inserts a new object into the container and returns the unique identifier that the container has been associated to the object. The identifier can be reused again when the object is deleted from the container. If unfixed, the object can be removed from the buffer. Otherwise, it has to be kept in the buffer until an unfix() is called.
After an insertion all the iterators operating on the container can be in an invalid state.
This method also allows an insertion of a null object. In the application would really like to have such objects in the container, some methods have to be modified.
Parameters:
object - is the new object.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the identifier of the object.

insert

public Object insert(Object object)
Inserts a new object into the container and returns the unique identifier. This methods behaves like insert(object, true).
Parameters:
object - is the new object.
Returns:
the identifier of the object.

insertAll

public Iterator insertAll(Iterator objects,
                          boolean unfix)
Inserts all objects of a given Iterator into the container. It returns an iterator that contains the identifiers of the new objects.
Note, that the order of the identifiers corresponds to the order of their objects. The meaning of unfix is the same as for the method insert. The default implementation is based on the functional concept (see class Function) and processes the input in a lazy fashion. An insertion of an object is performed when the application program operates on the output iterator!
Parameters:
objects - an iterator of objects that should be inserted.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
an iterator containing the identifiers of the objects of the input iterator.

insertAll

public Iterator insertAll(Iterator objects)
Inserts all objects of a given Iterator into the container. This method behaves like insertAll(objects, true).
Parameters:
objects - an iterator of objects that should be inserted.
Returns:
an iterator containing the identifiers of the objects of the input iterator.

objects

public Cursor objects()
Returns a cursor containing all objects of the container. The order in which the cursor delivers the objects is not specified.
The default implementation decorates the iterator that is returned by the method ids(). The objects are retrieved from the container by using the method get().
Returns:
a cursor containing all objects of the container.

objectIdConverter

public abstract Converter objectIdConverter()
Returns a converter for the ids generated by this container. A converter transforms an object to its byte representation and vice versa - also known as serialization in Java.
Since the identifier may have an arbitrary type (which has to be known in the container), the container has to provide such a method when the data is not stored in main memory.
Returns:
a converter for serializing the identifiers of the container.

remove

public abstract void remove(Object id)
                     throws NoSuchElementException
Removes the object with identifier id. An exception is thrown when an object with an identifier id is not in the container.
After a call of remove() all the iterators (and cursors) can be in an invalid state.
Parameters:
id - an identifier of an object.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id is not in the container.

removeAll

public void removeAll(Iterator ids)
Removes the objects with the identifiers given by the iterator ids.
The default implementation calls remove(id) for each identifier of ids.
Parameters:
ids - an iterator containing identifiers of objects.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier of ids is not in the container.

size

public abstract int size()
Returns the number of elements of the container.
Returns:
the number of elements.

unfix

public void unfix(Object id)
           throws NoSuchElementException
Unfixes the Object with identifier id. This method throws an exception when no element with an identifier id is in the container. After one call of unfix the buffer is allowed to remove the object (although the objects have been fixed more than once).
The default implementation only checks whether an object with identifier id is in the buffer.
Parameters:
id - identifier of an object that should be unfixed in the buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if no element with an identifier id is in the container.

unfixAll

public void unfixAll(Iterator ids)
Unfixes the objects with identifiers given by iterator ids. All the objects are unfixed which belong to one of the identifiers of ids.
The default implementation calls the method unfix() for each identifier of ids.
Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if no element with an identifier of ids is in the container.

update

public abstract void update(Object id,
                            Object object,
                            boolean unfix)
                     throws NoSuchElementException
Overwrites an existing (id,*)-element by (id, object). This method throws an exception if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.
Parameters:
id - identifier of the element.
object - the new object that should be associated to id.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

update

public void update(Object id,
                   Object object)
Overwrites an existing (id,*)-element by (id, object). This method throws an exception if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container. The default implementation only consists of a call of update(id, object, true).
Parameters:
id - identifier of the element.
object - the new object that should be associated to id.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

updateAll

public void updateAll(Iterator ids,
                      Function function,
                      boolean unfix)
Overwrites the elements of a container whose identifiers are given by iterator ids. For each identifier of ids, this method calls update(id, function.invoke(id)).
Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers.
function - a function that computes the object which should be associated to an identifier.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier of ids does not exist in the container.

updateAll

public void updateAll(Iterator ids,
                      Function function)
Overwrites the elements of a container whose identifiers are given by iterator ids. This method is equivalent to updateAll(ids, function, true).
Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers.
function - a function that computes the object which should be associated to an identifier.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier of ids does not exist in the container.

updateAll

public void updateAll(Iterator ids,
                      Iterator objects,
                      boolean unfix)
Overwrites the elements of a container whose identifiers are given by iterator ids. The objects that have to be associated to the elements are also given as an iterator.
Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers
objects - an iterator of objects
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier of ids does not exist in the container.

updateAll

public void updateAll(Iterator ids,
                      Iterator objects)
Overwrites the elements of a container whose identifiers are given by iterator ids. This method is equivalent to updateAll(ids, objects, true).
Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers
objects - an iterator of objects
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier of ids does not exist in the container.
